subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: * A {{w|CJK Compatibility Ideographs|CJK compatibility ideograph}} exists at U+F967 with no change in glyph appearance.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: This character is not to be confused with visually similar but unrelated {{l|mul|𣎴}} (U+233B4) or {{l|mul|𤓯}} (U+244EF).

subSections.title: Descendants
subSections.text:
* {{l|ja|ふ}} ''({{w|Hiragana}} character derived from {{w|Man'yōgana}})''
* {{l|ja|フ}} ''({{w|Katakana}} character derived from {{w|Man'yōgana}})''

subSections.title: References
Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}

{{liushu|p}}.

The character {{lang|zh|不}} originated as a pictograph of the [[calyx]] of a flower. It was then composed into a phono-semantic character with the pictograph for mouth ({{zh-l|*口}}), to form {{och-l|否}}, representing “no” (negation). This composed meaning then spread back to the original character {{lang|zh|不}}, making it a synonym of {{lang|zh|否}}. A new character of {{och-l|柎}} was eventually created to represent the original meaning of calyx.

Following ''{{w|Shuowen}}''’s interpretation, [[w:Bernhard Karlgren|Karlgren]] and [[w:Léon Wieger|Wieger]] interpret it as a bird flying toward the sky ({{zh-l|*一}}). The sky being the limit for the bird, thus the idea of negation.
